moves.1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 Nf6 4. O-O Be:
Here Black could have been a bit more aggressive, with Bc5.
Alternative variation: 4...Nxe4? 5.Re1 Nd6 6.Nxe5 += [Black cannot take 6... Bxb5, otherwise 7. Nxc6 and the black Queen is lost. But the position is already bad for black.]
moves.5. Re1: White chooses to defend e4 with the Rook (instead of Nc3) to occupy the e-file and to build a strong center with c3-d4-Nd2.
moves.5... O-O 6. c3 a6: Black should have acted against White's plans by either Re8 or d6.
moves.7. Ba4:
White strangely does not take the Nc3, which is normal in the Ruy-Lopez: moreover, Black has casted already, so the Bb5 is not threatening the fork in case Black plays d6 or d5.
Alternative variation: 7.Bxc6 [Better would have been to take the Nc3, the only defender of e5.] 7...bxc6 [Take with b7 instead of d7 to open the b-file for the R and to allow d5 later.] 8.Nxe5 Rb8
moves.7... d6 8. h3 b5 9. Bb3 Na5 10. Bc2 Bb7: Black seems better developed so he tries to free up the game crushing White's center.
moves.12. d5: White tries to close the game, maybe to prepare an attack on the King-side. But he's still underdeveloped and most of his pieces are on the Queen-side.
moves.12... Qc7 13. b3 Bc8: Make some space for Na5 and shift some power on the King-side, just in case.
moves.14. Nbd2 Ne8 15. Nf1: Characteristic move of the Ruy-Lopez, to prepare an attack on the King-side.
moves.15... f5 16. Nf1h2: The N seems more effective in e3 or g3, bulding up some pressure on f5.
moves.16... Nb7: This is a loss of time. Action is on the King-side, and Black should continue with the idea started with f7-5, either by f4 or fxe4.
moves.17. Kh1: With this move White shows his intention to move Rg1 in order to continue his attack. Therefore, Black should take advantange of that and take fxe4.
moves.17... f4:
Black should have taken fxe4.
Alternative variation: 17...fxe4 18.Rxe4 c4 =+ [And Black's Knights have two beautiful squares to occupy: c5 and f6.]
moves.18. Rg1 c4 19. b4 Bd7: To put some pressure on the Queen-side, but there seems to be enough already. Better would be Nf6.
moves.20. a3 Nf6 21. Bd2 a5 22. Qe2 h6: Not sure what's this for. A waiting move maybe. But it weakens Black's King-side.
moves.23. a4 axb4 24. cxb4 Rfc8 25. Bc3 bxa4: Now Black has two powerful passed pawns, backed up by his Rooks.
moves.26. Nd2 a3 27. g4: White tries an attack on the King-side in order to shift the attention from his falling Queen-side.
moves.27... Nd8 28. g5: White does not seem to have enough power to break through Black's King-side.
moves.28... hxg5 29. Rxg5 Ne8:
White's Rook is hanging and Black should take advantage of it. Instead, with fear, he defends g7 (and attack Rg5) but without taking the initiative.
Alternative variation: 29...Nxd5
moves.30. Rh5 g6: This weakens the already weak g2 and it fails to threaten Rh5 because of the next-to-come fork Rg1.
moves.31. Rg1 Kg7 32. f3: Make some room for the Queen to get to g2.
moves.32... Nf7 33. Qg2 g5 34. h4 Qd8: Much better would be Kg6, trapping Rh5.
moves.35. hxg5 Nxg5 36. Rxg5+:
White aims to simplify the game, but this move clears the board of many pieces and the two Black's passed pawns increase their value.
Alternative variation: 36.Ng4 a2 37.Nxe5 a1=Q 38.Rxa1 Rxa1+ 39.Bxa1 +/- [And Black's position look really bad, with his King completely exposed.]
moves.36... Bxg5 37. Qxg5+ Qxg5 38. Rxg5+ Kf6: Black should lose no time and push his pawn a3.
Again a weak move from Black. Better would be Nh5.
moves.44. Rg1 Bxb3 45. Bxb3 Nc7 46. Rg7+ Kf8 4: Black fails to see Rh8+, but just for few moves. Time is running out.
White was already busted, but this move is the definitive mistake.
